prior_works.title: Generalization performance of support vector machines and other pattern classifiers
prior_works.authors: John Shawe-Taylor, Peter L. Bartlett, Robert C. Williamson, Martin Anthony
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the canonical dependence of generalization on the margin via fat-shattering (radius–margin), providing the baseline structural form that the new paper refines to be asymptotically tight across all parameters.

prior_works.title: The sample complexity of pattern classification with margin
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Gave early margin-dependent sample complexity bounds that the new work sharpens by calibrating the exact asymptotic tradeoff among margin size, sample size, and failure probability.

prior_works.title: Rademacher and Gaussian complexities: Risk bounds and structural results
prior_works.role: Data-dependent complexity framework underlying modern margin bounds
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the Rademacher-complexity machinery used to derive tight, high-probability bounds, which the new paper leverages to pin down optimal dependence on n and δ for large-margin halfspaces.

prior_works.title: Empirical margin distributions and bounding the generalization error
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced bounds that depend on the empirical margin distribution (i.e., the fraction of examples achieving a given margin), directly motivating the new paper’s precise accounting of the fraction-of-margin term.

prior_works.title: PAC-Bayes & Margins
prior_works.role: PAC-Bayesian margin bounds with sharp δ dependence
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided high-probability margin bounds with explicit failure-probability control, informing the new result’s asymptotically tight δ dependence in the margin–fraction–sample tradeoff.

prior_works.title: Local Rademacher complexities
prior_works.authors: Peter L. Bartlett, Olivier Bousquet, Shahar Mendelson
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Developed localization tools for fast-rate, high-probability bounds that the new work adapts to achieve tight asymptotics for halfspaces while tracking the fraction of points at the target margin.

prior_works.title: Boosting the Margin: A New Explanation for the Effectiveness of Voting Methods
prior_works.authors: Robert E. Schapire, Yoav Freund, Peter L. Bartlett, Wee Sun Lee
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how generalization can hinge on the distribution of margins (not just the minimum), a perspective mirrored and specialized by the new paper to halfspaces with explicit dependence on the fraction achieving a given margin.

synthesis_narrative: The modern theory of margin-based generalization originates with fat-shattering analyses for linear separators, notably the radius–margin framework of Shawe-Taylor, Bartlett, Williamson, and Anthony and Bartlett’s margin sample-complexity results. These works fixed the structural dependence of risk on geometric margin, but did not completely resolve how the bound should scale—simultaneously and sharply—with sample size and failure probability. Subsequent advances in data-dependent complexity, especially Bartlett and Mendelson’s Rademacher framework and localized complexities with Bartlett, Bousquet, and Mendelson, enabled sharper, high-probability bounds by tying error to empirical complexity at the achieved margin scale. In parallel, the margin-distribution viewpoint—pioneered in boosting by Schapire et al. and formalized for general classifiers by Koltchinskii and Panchenko—highlighted that the relevant quantity is not just a single margin but the fraction of points exceeding a margin threshold. PAC-Bayesian margin bounds (Langford and Shawe-Taylor) further clarified the optimal dependence on the failure probability. The NeurIPS 2025 paper synthesizes these strands for large-margin halfspaces and closes remaining gaps: it isolates the precise, asymptotically tight interplay among (i) the margin level, (ii) the fraction of training examples attaining that margin, (iii) the sample size, and (iv) the failure probability. By integrating margin-distribution control with localized, high-probability complexity analysis specialized to halfspaces, it matches upper and lower rates across all parameters, delivering the first bound that is tight in this full tradeoff.
